summary: Official notification from the Federal Bureau of Prisons to two federal judges regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein by apparent suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019. The letter details the discovery of Epstein unresponsive in his cell, emergency response, his death at a hospital, and the pending investigations by the FBI and DOJ Inspector General.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the letter, found unresponsive in his cell at MCC and pronounced dead at the hospital on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: One of the federal judges to whom the notification letter regarding Epstein's death is addressed.

persons.name: Richard M. Berman
persons.context: One of the federal judges to whom the notification letter regarding Epstein's death is addressed.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center around 6:30 am, transported to a hospital, and pronounced dead at 7:37 am. The incident is under investigation as an apparent suicide.

events.title: FBI and DOJ Investigations Initiated
events.description: The FBI is actively investigating Epstein's death, and the Attorney General has requested the DOJ Office of the Inspector General to also look into the matter.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
New York Presbyterian-Lower Manhattan Hospital, New York, New York
Daniel Patrick Moynihan United States Courthouse, 500 Pearl Street, New York, New York 10007-1312
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died on August 10, 2019, at approximately 7:37 a.m. at New York Presbyterian-Lower Manhattan Hospital.
Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell in the Special Housing Unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center around 6:30 a.m. from an apparent suicide.
The FBI is actively investigating the incident, and the Attorney General has requested the DOJ Office of the Inspector General to also investigate.
An autopsy is pending to determine the official cause of death.
The letter is official correspondence from the Bureau of Prisons to Chief Judge Colleen McMahon and District Judge Richard M. Berman, who were overseeing Epstein's case.
